title: Ticket #2071: Cross stduniv tests aren't flexible enough
description:
In a cross test scenario, it turns out that the stduniv tests are condor_compiled on the native host and submitted on the target host. It should really that each stduniv test should have available two executables, one condor_compiled on the native platform, and on condor_compiled on the target platform, and both used for a test.

Having it the way it does now minimizes the usefulness of cross tests of standard universe for compatibility testing.

I've been hacking on this to try and remake the condor_tests directory on the execute machine, but it is proving difficult for strange reasons that are time consuming to debug.

2011-May-18 15:32:16 by psilord:
Ok, here is what I've found.

cmake embeds absolute paths into the generated Makefiles. So, when a build of Condor happens on Machine A in some condor execute directory Ad, Ad is spread all through the Makefile.

Then, when running the test job of the build from A Machine B, I simply try to make clean and remake the condor_tests directory in the test glue's remote_pre. However, this fails terribly trying to chdir/whatever to Ad, which doesn't exist.

To regenerate the Makefiles, we need to run cmake, to run cmake, we need as input basically the whole source release from Machine A. I don't think that is available.

2011-May-18 16:12:28 by psilord:
I'm going to declare this activity a rathole and skip this step in the RHEL 6 porting.

This means that we have to hand test to see if the RHEL 5's stduniv will condor_compile on a rhel 6 machine the stduniv test suite.
